description: Adagio Bud & Breakfast CEO Joel Schneider stands in front of his buisiness on Race Street in Denver, Colorado. Schneider and his wife moved from New York to start a series of "cannalodging" businesses. (Photo by Dom DiFurio | News21)

Adagio Bud & Breakfast is a cannabis-friendly lodging option for tourists in an historic neighborhood in Denver. Joel Schneider, the CEO, said the business doesn't advertise itself as a marijuana-friendly space out of concern for the safety and privacy of guests. (Photo by Dom DiFurio | News21)
Coffee mugs with the Bud & Breakfast logo are displayed on shelves along with glass pipes for smoking marijuana. (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)
Chef Stephen Avila prepares breakfast for customers at 9 a.m. every day for "wake and bake." (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)
Adagio Bud & Breakfast offers a variety of breakfast foods, such as this tray of pancakes and bacon. (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)
Guests are allowed to consume cannabis throughout the building. Paraphernalia such as bongs, rolling papers and trays are provided. (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)

Lisa Schneider, the director of hospitality for Adagio Bud & Breakfast, said she and her husband moved from New York to start a series of "cannalodging" businesses. (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)
Guests are encouraged to "wake and bake" with their own cannabis every morning in the Bud & Breakfast dining room. (Photo by Montinique Monroe | News21)
